PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Facility Manager is ultimately responsible for ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective, and compliant prevention program as required by 40 CFR 68.65 through 68.87 and OSHA PSM requirements.  General responsibilities for the Prevention Program Elements are listed below.

2.	Process Hazard Analysis (40 CFR 68.67)

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

In accordance with 40 CFR 68.90 through 68.95, the Facility Manager is responsible for:
•	Designing, implementing, and maintaining the facility’s Emergency Response Plan
•	Ensuring that all associated training is conducted and documented appropriately
•	Coordinating the site emergency response plan with the community emergency response plan
•	Responding to local emergency planners / responders when questions arise

G.  MANAGEMENT SYSTEM

INTRODUCTION

The Springtown Plant in Parker County, Texas is committed to being associated with unmatched environmental performance as measured by our employees, customers, regulators, and the public.  As part of our philosophy, our Facility Manager has overall responsibility for ensuring that the elements of the RMP Regulations are implemented on a timely basis.  The Facility Manager has assigned the responsibility of developing our risk management program to the Corporate RMP Team which has the necessary background, training, and experience to accomplish this task.  The Corporate RMP Team will interface with the Facility Manager and other necessary personnel (which may include third-party consultants) to ensure proper communication / coordination for implementation of the RMP Management System.  

RESPONSIBILITIES FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM ELEMENTS

The following sections identify the specific responsibilities for each aspect of our risk management and process safety management programs.

We encourage all interested citizens or community organizations to learn more about our latest information on emergency response for the county.  We plan to diligently integrate our response capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.

D.	 5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Five-year Accident History is described in the Executive Summary of the Risk Management Program and summarized in the Risk Management Program submitted to the EPA.  Records detailing each accident are in this section.  

In the previous five years, the Springtown Plant in Parker County, Texas has had no reportable accidents as described in 40 CFR §60.42(a).

However, there was a release of un-stabilized condensate vapors, a naturally occurring hydrocarbon mixture, prior to it entering the condensate stabilization unit on March 27, 2018.  Although this substance is not required to be included within the Risk Management Program per 40 CFR §68.115, Colt has decided to include this incident because of its significant nature.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

Diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework on which we will continue to improve the level of safety at the Springtown Plant.  Some of the key components of the safety improvements we expect to achieve are as follows:

•	The Management of Change provisions ensures that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any change we make to process chemicals, technology, equipment, or procedures.  
•	The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in our

nt.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a reoccurrence, and forwards these results to the business management team for resolution.  

Compliance Audits:  To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Springtown Plant periodically conducts an audit to determine whether procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit team members.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to the Springtown Plant management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team’s findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.  

Five-year Accident History

No incident resulting in onsite or offsite impacts from an accidental release of a regulated substance from a covered process has occurred at the Springtown Plant within the last five years.  Although we take pride in that record, we also place daily emphasis on our prevention and safety programs to ensure this record continues.  

However, there was a release of un-stabilized condensate vapors, a naturally occurring hydrocarbon mixture, prior to it entering the condensate stabilization unit on March 27, 2018.  Although this substance is not required to be included within the Risk Management Program per 40 CFR §68.115, Colt has decided to include this incident because of its significant nature.  A summary of the incident is included in Section D.  

Emergency Response Program

Safe Work Practices:  The Springtown Plant has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous substances before process piping and equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e. hot work), and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.  

Management of Change:  The Springtown Plant has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all covered processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls have not been compromised by the changes. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.  

Incident Investigation: The Springtown Plant promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to gather the facts, determine the root cause, and develop corrective action to prevent the reoccurrence of the incident or a similar incide

Contractors:  The Springtown Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have appropriate skills, (3) are aware of the hazards of their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site specific safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with orientation sessions pertaining to these key points.  

Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR):  The Springtown Plant conducts a PSSR on any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.  

Mechanical Integrity:  The Springtown Plant has well-established practices and procedures for maintaining process equipment.  The basic aspects of this program include (1) training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting equipment defic

d associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response / exposure treatment consideration, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs).

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):  Springtown Plant has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The facility primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) method analysis technique to perform these evaluations.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.  Periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating.  
 

Operating Procedures:  Springtown Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures provide guidance for experienced operators and provide the basis for training new operators. Operating procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The review and certification process involves both operators and technical staff.  

Training:  In addition to training on operating procedures, the facility has a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in the process.  Employees receive basic training on the operating procedures when they are first assigned to the plant as well

Employee Participation:  Active employee participation and involvement in the development and implementation of Springtown Plant’s PSM program is an important step toward achieving the objective to prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of toxic, reactive, flammable, or explosive chemicals.  Employee involvement will help to ensure that all perspectives regarding PSM are considered, and that the best ideas are implemented. Springtown Plant strongly promotes employee involvement in safety issues through the following existing programs: regularly scheduled safety meetings, tail-gate safety meetings, Hazard Communication, Safety Suggestion Forms, emergency response training, and special training programs (First Aid, etc.).   Additionally, all employees, contractors, and visitors have stop work authority when potentially unsafe conditions are observed.

Process Safety Information (PSI):  Complete and accurately written PSI concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment is essential to an effective PSM and RMP program and to completing and maintaining a process hazard analysis (PHA). PSI is readily available to all employees.  The Springtown Plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process. Based on the analysis using the EPAs RMP*Comp ™ calculations, the worst-case scenario resulted from one of the fifteen 30,000-gallon un-stabilized condensate vessels (401,495 pounds/vessel). The analysis assumed the entire contents of the tank was vapor. The calculated distance at which a resulting vapor cloud explosion could cause an overpressure of 1 psi is approximately 0.6-miles (3,168 feet). An overpressure of 1 psi is the EPA’s threshold for measurable impacts.  

2010 Census Data, provided through the EPA MARPLOT Version 5.1.1, identifies that approximately 179 people and 70 residencies are within the impact area (0.6-mile radius from each 30,000-gallon un-stabilized condensate vessel).  Based on a Google Maps aerial review the property surrounding the Springtown Plant within a 0.6-mile radius is a mixture of agriculture, residential, industrial, and commercial properties. Impacted properties include schools, recreation areas, and churches. Potential environmental impacts include the Dry Branch to Walnut Creek.

Un-stabilized condensate has not been processed and would typically be considered a naturally occurring hydrocarbon that is not regulated by the Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule.  In the event that stabilized condensate may be stored in these tanks at a future date, the total volume of flammable material stored at the site has been calculated to include the maximum capacity of all the tankage at the plant.  There are no threshold quantities of toxic substances present.  As such, the Springtown Gas Plant is classified as a Program 3 RMP facility.
 

The processing plant portion of the plant’s operations has been discontinued and the propane utilized as refrigeration gas, essential for the processing plant to operate, has been removed.  The plant now operates essentially as a large compressor station and a condensate stabilization plant.  

The compression station operation essentially consists of bring in in field natural gas by pipeline and then compressing the gas prior to be transporting off-site by pipeline to another gas processing plant.  During the compression process liquids are removed either through gravity, pressure differentiation or through glycol dehydration.  

The condensate stabilization unit (CSU) process consists of taking un-stabilized condensate brought in by truck or as drip from the compression station process and stabilizing it by removing the lighter volatiles entrapped in the liquid and then trucking out the stabilized condensate to sales.  Un-stabilized condensate transported to the site is placed into pressurized bullet tanks and piped through the condensate stabilization unit where it is heated to help release lighter organic carbons from the liquid.  After the condensate is stabilized, the condensate is stored in another set of bullet tanks until transported off-site by truck.  The organic carbons released during the process are captured

A.	 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Introduction and Policies

The Springtown Plant, owned and operated by Colt G&P (North Texas) L.P., is committed to the same quality of safety and environmental excellence that all other Colt assets promote.  This philosophy involves making each and every employee and contractor accountable for their own safety as well as that of the community around them.  As a company we follow a close adherence to all applicable federal, state, and local laws to ensure a safe and healthy environment for all.

Employees who enter the Springtown Plant complete a thorough training, both in the classroom and on-the-job, that enables them to address emergency issues as they arise.  This preparation includes standard operational, emergency operational, and release prevention training.  In addition, periodic refresher courses help to keep operators’ problem-solving abilities up to date and in sync with our recurring safety improvements.  Our regular internal audits provide an excellent checks and balances system for monitoring the high standards that are set.

The Springtown Gas Plant is a natural gas plant that extracts natural gas liquids (NGLs) from natural gas.   The facility operates a variety of processes to recover petroleum products (e.g., natural gas and condensate) from field gas.  Twelve 30,000-gallon Un-stabilized Condensate tanks, two 25,000-gallon Un-stabilized Condensate tanks, one 20,000-gallon Un-stabilized Condensate tank, and three 60,000-gallon Stabilized Condensate tanks are used to store mix flammable condensate liquid at the plant.  There is also one 18,000-gallon NGL tank and one 30,000-gallon Propane tank, both empty and not in use, at the facility.  The facility consists of multiple small lube oil, waste oil, condensate and fuel tanks and their associated piping, valves, pumps, and compressors on site that support the compressor station as well as the pressurized condensate tanks.
